ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Brainstem lesion (likely contusion)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of CNS trauma with crossed signs (left auditory, right somatic), absent left reflexes, abnormal left ABR (later waves), and central deficits with normal cortical function (Frequency Patterns).

ordered_list.rationale_short: Evaluate neural synchrony and brainstem integrity.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presents with normal peripheral hearing sensitivity but significant retrocochlear signs localized to the left brainstem. Key findings include absent left contralateral reflexes, abnormal left ABR (reduced/absent waves IV-V), and severe deficits on left-ear central tasks (dichotic and monaural low-redundancy). Normal Frequency Patterns suggest cortical sparing, while normal MLD suggests some lower brainstem pathway preservation. The pattern of 'crossed' signs (left auditory, right somatic) is consistent with a left brainstem lesion.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilaterally normal thresholds with no asymmetry.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Absent left ear stimulation; present right ear at normal levels (500-4000 Hz).

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear normal. Left ear normal waves I-III, but reduced/absent IV-V complex; no response at 60 dB nHL.

tests.name: Masking Level Difference (MLD)
tests.result_summary: Normal (10 dB) for 500 Hz pulsed tones.

tests.name: Central Auditory Battery
tests.result_summary: Marked left ear deficits: Competing Sentences (Left 0%, Right 100%), Dichotic Digits (Left ~60%, Right ~80%), SSW (Left ~45%, Right ~90%), LPFS (Left ~10%, Right ~80%). Frequency Patterns normal (100% bilateral). Dichotic Rhymes (obtained at follow-up) showed Left 0%, Right ~75-80%.

proposed_items: Coping strategies for listening in noise
counseling_actions: Validate patient's complaints by explaining the discrepancy between normal volume detection and impaired processing
Explain the role of the brainstem in filtering background noise
Discuss prognosis of slow but potential improvement

red_flags_present: Neurological signs (right facial paresis, right-handed numbness, ptosis)

escalation.rationale_short: Patient is already under neurology care for the diagnosed brainstem contusion; audiology provides monitoring and rehabilitation.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor recovery of central auditory function and tinnitus status.

expected_outcome: Hearing generally improved somewhat, though difficulty in noise persisted.
Neuroaudiological test results improved slightly over several years.
Patient developed coping strategies that were of moderate help.
